findings.reasoning: The finding identifies that static signatures can be reused until expiration. This is the intended design of a 'static signature' mechanism (pre-approving a specific hash for a duration), not a vulnerability. The mechanism relies on the uniqueness of the operation hash (which includes transaction details) to prevent unintended replays, rather than a nonce. The model's suggestion to invalidate after first use would fundamentally break the intended functionality of allowing multiple executions of the same pre-approved operation (e.g., recurring payments).

The finding claims that 'timestamp <= block.timestamp' allows execution at the exact expiration time, which it argues is a vulnerability. This is a theoretical concern without a concrete, profitable exploit scenario. Standard smart contract practice allows execution at the exact expiration timestamp (inclusive). The 'manipulation' scenario described (executing at time T when expiration is T) is simply using the feature as designed until the very last second it is valid. There is no security boundary being crossed here.

notes: The model failed to identify the actual target vulnerability (logic error in recoverSapientSignature returning a constant instead of the image hash). Instead, it focused on the static signature mechanism in signatureValidation, raising design choices and theoretical concerns as vulnerabilities.
